--- ## QCD in the Continuum
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} =-\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}\left[ F_{\mu\nu} F^{\mu\nu}\right]+\sum_{f=1}^{N_f} \bar{\psi}_f \big( i \gamma^\mu D_\mu - m_f \big) \psi_f$$
## QCD in the Continuum {auto-animate=true auto-animate-easing="ease-in-ease-out" auto-animate-duration=1}
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} =\textcolor{#EB811B}{-\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}\left[F_{\mu\nu} F^{\mu\nu}\right]} +\sum_{f=1}^{N_f} \bar{\psi}_f \big( i \gamma^\mu D_\mu - m_f \big)\psi_f$$
:::: {.columns } ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Gauge fields**:
$$\normalsize A_\mu(x) = \sum_{a=1}^8 A_\mu^a(x)\, T^a$$
- $\small \left[ T_a,T_b\right]= i f_{abc}T_c$ and $\small \left\{ T_a,T_b\right\}= \frac 1 2 \delta_{ab}$ - $\small A_\mu(x)$ encapsulates the 8 gluons - $\small A_\mu^a(x)\in \mathfrak{su}(3)$. ::: ::: {class="fragment"} - **Field strength tensor**:
$$ F_{\mu\nu} = \partial_\mu A_\nu - \partial_\nu A_\mu - i g \,[A_\mu, A_\nu] $$
::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Gauge transformations**: $\small \forall\; U(x) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$
$$ \begin{array}{rcl} A_\mu & \longrightarrow & UA_\mu U^\dagger \\ F_{\mu\nu} & \longrightarrow & U\,F_{\mu\nu}\,U^\dagger \end{array} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-27px"} - **Covariance**: - $\small F_{\mu\nu}$ transforms *homogeneously* - $\small \mathrm{Tr}[F_{\mu\nu}F^{\mu\nu}]$ is **gauge invariant** ::: ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="font-size:1.0em; font-style:italic; color:gray; margin-top:-20px; margin-right:0px; text-align:right;"} **[Pure gauge]{style="color: #EB811B;"} → already highly non-trivial:** confinement, glueballs, non-linear self-interactions... ::: ## QCD in the Continuum
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} = -\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}\left[F_{\mu\nu} F^{\mu\nu}\right] +\textcolor{#EB811B}{\sum_{f=1}^{N_f} \bar{\psi}_f \big( i \gamma^\mu D_\mu - m_f \big)\psi_f}$$
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Quark fields**: - $\small \psi_f(x)$ → flavor $\small f=1,\dots,N_f$ - Real world → $\small N_f = 6$ - Fundamental rep. of $\small \mathrm{SU}(3)_C$ - $\small \psi_f(x)$ → $\small (\textcolor{red}{\psi_f(x)}, \textcolor{green}{\psi_f(x)}, \textcolor{blue}{\psi_f(x)})$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" } - **Covariant derivative**: $$D_\mu = \partial_\mu - i g A_\mu$$ - Couples quarks to gluons - Ensures **local gauge invariance** ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Gauge transformations**: $\small \forall\; U(x) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$
$$ \begin{array}{rcl} \psi_f & \longrightarrow & U\,\psi_f \\ \bar{\psi}_f & \longrightarrow & \bar{\psi}_f\,U^\dagger \\ D_\mu \psi_f & \longrightarrow & U\,D_\mu \psi_f \end{array} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-27px"} - **Facts**: Quarks are never observed as free particles - Combined into **color singlets** → hadrons - mesons ( $\small \pi^{\pm}, \pi^0\dots$) - baryons ( $\small p,n\dots$) ::: ::: :::: ## Interactions in QCD ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1"} **Gauge invariance** not only dictates the kinetic terms, but also **fixes the interaction structure**: ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:10px; margin-left:120px; justify-content:center; font-size:1.3em; font-weight:200;"} $\small \sim g \bar{\psi}\psi A$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:-54px; margin-left:550px; justify-content:center; font-size:1.3em; font-weight:200;"} $\small \sim g \partial A A A \quad \quad \quad \sim g^2 AAAA$ ::: :::{.r-hstack style="align-items:center; justify-content:center; margin-top:-10px;"} ::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-35px;"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3"} - **QED-like vertex** - quark–gluon interaction - analogous to electron–photon in QED ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-35px;"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6"} - **New in QCD** - 3-gluon and 4-gluon self-interactions - consequence of non-abelian $\mathrm{SU}(3)_C$ - lead to confinement, asymptotic freedom, glueballs... ::: ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:left;"} Quantum corrections lead to divergencies: Interactions are treated in the **renormalization framework** → [**running**]{style="color: #EB811B;"} of the coupling $g(\mu)$. ::: ## Running of the Coupling :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Scale dependent** coupling: $\small g \,\longrightarrow\, g(\mu)$ ::: ::: {class="fragment"} - Governed by the **β-function**: $$\small \mu \frac{dg}{d\mu} = \beta(g), \quad \beta(g) = -\beta_0 \frac{g^3}{16\pi^2} + \mathcal{O}(g^5) $$ with $\small \;\beta_0 = \tfrac{11}{3} - \tfrac{2}{3} N_f$ ::: ::: {class="fragment"} - **Solution at 1-loop**: $$\small \alpha_s(\mu) \equiv \frac{g^2(\mu)}{4\pi} = \frac{1}{\beta_0 \ln(\mu^2 / \Lambda_{\text{QCD}}^2)} $$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"}
::: :::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-60px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Consequences**: - $\small \mu \to \infty \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; \alpha_s(\mu) \to 0 \;\Rightarrow\; \color{#EB811B}\text{asymptotic freedom}$ - $\small \mu \to \Lambda_{\text{QCD}} \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; \alpha_s(\mu) \gg 1 \;\Rightarrow\; \color{#EB811B}\text{confinement}$ ::: ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:10px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:right;"} QCD becomes strongly coupled in the IR → [**non-perturbative tools**]{style="color: #EB811B;"} are required! ::: ## Confinement :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"} - **QCD potential**:
$$\small V(r) = -\,\frac{4}{3}\frac{\alpha_s}{r} + \sigma r \quad \quad \quad \;\sigma \approx 0.9\ \mathrm{GeV/fm} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-20px;"} - **Force**:
$$ \small |dV/dr|_{\mathrm{QCD}} \approx 0.9 \times 1.6\cdot10^{-10} \text{J}/10^{-15}\ \text{m} \approx 1.6\cdot10^{4}\ \text{N} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment fade-in-then-semi-out" data-fragment-index="4" style="position:absolute; left:267px; top:207px;"} ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5" style="margin-top:-40px; margin-left:25px;"}
$\small |dV/dr|_{\mathrm{QED}} \approx 2.3 \cdot 10^{2} \ \mathrm{N}$
::: ::: {class="fragment fade-in-then-semi-out" data-fragment-index="6" style="position:absolute; left:-40px; top:250px;"} ::: ::: {.callout type='default' class="fragment" data-fragment-index="8" style="margin-top:130px; width:fit-content; margin-left:20px; margin-right:20px; margin-bottom:50px;"} ## Particle Data Group ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="7" style="text-align:center; font-style:italic; margin-top:30px; font-size:0.9em;"} **Open problem:** No general *analytic proof* of color confinement in QCD is known. (It is one of the Clay Millennium Prize problems.) ::: ::: :::: ## QCD at Low Energies :::: {.columns} ::: {.column style="margin-top:40px; width:65%;" } ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:80px;} - For $\mu \sim \Lambda_{\text{QCD}}$: - $\alpha_s(\mu)$ is large - Perturbation theory breaks down ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"} - QCD physics is dominated by **non-perturbative phenomena**: - Confinement - Mass gap - Hadron spectrum & structure ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3"} - Need appropriate **Low Enery tools**: - **Lattice QCD** (first-principles numerical approach) - **Effective Field Theories** (low-energy approximations) ::: ::: ::: {.column width="35%"} ::: :::: ## Lattice QCD :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="65%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:5px;"} - **Euclidean formulation**: Discretize space-time as a **4D grid** ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - Introduces two natural **cutoffs**: - **UV** : lattice spacing $a$ - **IR** : finite size $L$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - **Fields on the lattice**: - Quarks: $\;\psi(x) \;\;\to\;\; a^{-3/2}\psi(n)$ (sites) - Gauge fields: $\;A_\mu(x) \;\;\to\;\; U_\mu(n) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$ (links) ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - Gauge links act as **parallel transporters** ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - **Boundary conditions**: - Periodic (PBC) for gauge fields - Anti-periodic (APBC) for fermions ::: ::: ::: {.column width="35%"}
::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-20px; margin-left:400px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:right;"} QCD becomes a set of **dimensionless variables**
It can be solved numerically using **[Monte Carlo techniques]{style="color: #EB811B;"}** ::: ## Monte Carlo methods
$$ \langle \mathcal{O}\rangle = \frac{1}{Z}\int [dU]\textcolor{blue}{[d\bar\psi d\psi]}\,\mathcal{O}\, e^{-S_G[U]-\textcolor{blue}{\bar\psi} D[U]\textcolor{blue}{\psi}} = \frac{1}{Z}\int [dU]\,\mathcal{O}_F[U]\,\textcolor{blue}{\det D[U]}\,e^{-S_G[U]} $$
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="70%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:-20px; margin-bottom:-30px;"} 1. **Importance sampling** Draw gauge configurations $\small \left\{ U_\mu^{(i)} \right\}$ from:
$$ \mathcal{P}[U]\propto e^{-S_G[U]}\,\det D[U] $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px;"} 2. $\small \forall i$ compute **observable** $\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_F[U^{(i)}]$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px; margin-bottom:-20px;"} 3. Ensemble average (**estimator**)
$$ \overline{\mathcal{O}} \;=\; \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_F[U^{(i)}] \;=\; \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle \;+\; \delta\mathcal{O} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-30px;"} 4. Set the **physical scale** $\small a$ (e.g. hadron masses) ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px;"} 5. **Continuum / infinite-volume limits**:
- Remove the **UV** ($\small a \to 0$) and **IR** ($\small L \to \infty$) cut-off - (if needed) **chiral extrapolation** $\small m_q\to m_q^{\rm phys}$
::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ::: {.fragment style="margin-top:60px;"} | **Experiments** | **Lattice QCD** | |------------|------------| | Accelerators (LHC) | Ensemble of configurations | | Detectors (CMS, ATLAS) | Observables | ::: ::: :::: ## Why we need strong machines?
$$ \text{Computational cost} \sim c \;\times\; (\# \text{confs}) \;\times\; \left(\frac{1}{M_\pi}\right)^6 \;\times\; L^5 \;\times\; (a^{-1})^7 $$
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.fragment style="margin-top:-20px;"} - Cost grows rapidly when approaching: - **physical pion masses** - **large volumes** - **fine lattice spacing** ::: ::: {.fragment} - At the **physical point** with $L=32$: - Generating $3\times 10^3$

Hundreds of nodes with CPUs/GPUs 2. High memory per node 3. High network bandwidth ::: ::: :::: ## ### A remark: > "**Numerical simulations have the reputation of being an approximate method** that mainly serves to obtain qualitative information on the behaviour of complex systems.

This is, however, not so **in Lattice QCD**, where the **simulations produce results that are exact** (on the given lattice) **up to statistical errors**. The systematic uncertainties related to a non-zero lattice spacing and finite volume, still need to be investigated, but these effects are theoretically well understood, and can usually be brought under control."
— M. Lüscher
"Lattice QCD - From Quarks Confinement to Asymptotic Freedom"
## Chiral Symmetry in QCD :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1"} - **Massless QCD Lagrangian** $\small \mathrm{SU}(N_f)_L \times \mathrm{SU}(N_f)_R$ symmetry ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"} - **Exact Realization?** No! → We do not observe **parity doubling** ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3"} - Chiral symmetry is **broken**: - **Spontaneously**: $\langle \bar{\psi}\psi \rangle \neq 0$ - **Explicitly**: quark masses $m_q \neq 0$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4"} - Consequence: **Pseudo–Goldstone bosons** → light pions emerge ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5" style="margin-top:10px;"} - **Gell-Mann–Oakes–Renner (GMOR) relation**:
$$\small M_\pi^2 \;=\; (m_u + m_d)\frac{\langle \bar{\psi}\psi\rangle}{f_\pi^2} $$
::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6"} **Why an EFT?**
- At **low energies**, quarks & gluons are not convenient d.o.f. - Relevant excitations are **pions**
::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="7" style="margin-top:10px;"} **How?**
- Keep underlying symmetries - Expand in $p/\Lambda$ - Emergence of **Low Energy Constants**

:::: {.columns } ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Gauge fields**:
$$\normalsize A_\mu(x) = \sum_{a=1}^8 A_\mu^a(x)\, T^a$$

$$ F_{\mu\nu} = \partial_\mu A_\nu - \partial_\nu A_\mu - i g \,[A_\mu, A_\nu] $$
::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Gauge transformations**: $\small \forall\; U(x) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$
$$ \begin{array}{rcl} A_\mu & \longrightarrow & UA_\mu U^\dagger \\ F_{\mu\nu} & \longrightarrow & U\,F_{\mu\nu}\,U^\dagger \end{array} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-27px"} - **Covariance**: - $\small F_{\mu\nu}$ transforms *homogeneously* - $\small \mathrm{Tr}[F_{\mu\nu}F^{\mu\nu}]$ is **gauge invariant** ::: ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="font-size:1.0em; font-style:italic; color:gray; margin-top:-20px; margin-right:0px; text-align:right;"} **[Pure gauge]{style="color: #EB811B;"} → already highly non-trivial:** confinement, glueballs, non-linear self-interactions... ::: ## QCD in the Continuum
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} = -\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}\left[F_{\mu\nu} F^{\mu\nu}\right] +\textcolor{#EB811B}{\sum_{f=1}^{N_f} \bar{\psi}_f \big( i \gamma^\mu D_\mu - m_f \big)\psi_f}$$
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Quark fields**: - $\small \psi_f(x)$ → flavor $\small f=1,\dots,N_f$ - Real world → $\small N_f = 6$ - Fundamental rep. of $\small \mathrm{SU}(3)_C$ - $\small \psi_f(x)$ → $\small (\textcolor{red}{\psi_f(x)}, \textcolor{green}{\psi_f(x)}, \textcolor{blue}{\psi_f(x)})$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" } - **Covariant derivative**: $$D_\mu = \partial_\mu - i g A_\mu$$ - Couples quarks to gluons - Ensures **local gauge invariance** ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Gauge transformations**: $\small \forall\; U(x) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$
$$ \begin{array}{rcl} \psi_f & \longrightarrow & U\,\psi_f \\ \bar{\psi}_f & \longrightarrow & \bar{\psi}_f\,U^\dagger \\ D_\mu \psi_f & \longrightarrow & U\,D_\mu \psi_f \end{array} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-27px"} - **Facts**: Quarks are never observed as free particles - Combined into **color singlets** → hadrons - mesons ( $\small \pi^{\pm}, \pi^0\dots$) - baryons ( $\small p,n\dots$) ::: ::: :::: ## Interactions in QCD ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1"} **Gauge invariance** not only dictates the kinetic terms, but also **fixes the interaction structure**: ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:10px; margin-left:120px; justify-content:center; font-size:1.3em; font-weight:200;"} $\small \sim g \bar{\psi}\psi A$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:-54px; margin-left:550px; justify-content:center; font-size:1.3em; font-weight:200;"} $\small \sim g \partial A A A \quad \quad \quad \sim g^2 AAAA$ ::: :::{.r-hstack style="align-items:center; justify-content:center; margin-top:-10px;"} ::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-35px;"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3"} - **QED-like vertex** - quark–gluon interaction - analogous to electron–photon in QED ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-35px;"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6"} - **New in QCD** - 3-gluon and 4-gluon self-interactions - consequence of non-abelian $\mathrm{SU}(3)_C$ - lead to confinement, asymptotic freedom, glueballs... ::: ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:left;"} Quantum corrections lead to divergencies: Interactions are treated in the **renormalization framework** → [**running**]{style="color: #EB811B;"} of the coupling $g(\mu)$. ::: ## Running of the Coupling :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Scale dependent** coupling: $\small g \,\longrightarrow\, g(\mu)$ ::: ::: {class="fragment"} - Governed by the **β-function**: $$\small \mu \frac{dg}{d\mu} = \beta(g), \quad \beta(g) = -\beta_0 \frac{g^3}{16\pi^2} + \mathcal{O}(g^5) $$ with $\small \;\beta_0 = \tfrac{11}{3} - \tfrac{2}{3} N_f$ ::: ::: {class="fragment"} - **Solution at 1-loop**: $$\small \alpha_s(\mu) \equiv \frac{g^2(\mu)}{4\pi} = \frac{1}{\beta_0 \ln(\mu^2 / \Lambda_{\text{QCD}}^2)} $$ ::: ::: ::: {.column width="50%"}
::: :::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="50%"} ::: ::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-60px;"} ::: {class="fragment"} - **Consequences**: - $\small \mu \to \infty \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; \alpha_s(\mu) \to 0 \;\Rightarrow\; \color{#EB811B}\text{asymptotic freedom}$ - $\small \mu \to \Lambda_{\text{QCD}} \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; \alpha_s(\mu) \gg 1 \;\Rightarrow\; \color{#EB811B}\text{confinement}$ ::: ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:10px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:right;"} QCD becomes strongly coupled in the IR → [**non-perturbative tools**]{style="color: #EB811B;"} are required! ::: ## Confinement :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"} - **QCD potential**:
$$\small V(r) = -\,\frac{4}{3}\frac{\alpha_s}{r} + \sigma r \quad \quad \quad \;\sigma \approx 0.9\ \mathrm{GeV/fm} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-20px;"} - **Force**:
$$ \small |dV/dr|_{\mathrm{QCD}} \approx 0.9 \times 1.6\cdot10^{-10} \text{J}/10^{-15}\ \text{m} \approx 1.6\cdot10^{4}\ \text{N} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment fade-in-then-semi-out" data-fragment-index="4" style="position:absolute; left:267px; top:207px;"} ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5" style="margin-top:-40px; margin-left:25px;"}
$\small |dV/dr|_{\mathrm{QED}} \approx 2.3 \cdot 10^{2} \ \mathrm{N}$
::: ::: {class="fragment fade-in-then-semi-out" data-fragment-index="6" style="position:absolute; left:-40px; top:250px;"} ::: ::: {.callout type='default' class="fragment" data-fragment-index="8" style="margin-top:130px; width:fit-content; margin-left:20px; margin-right:20px; margin-bottom:50px;"} ## Particle Data Group ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="7" style="text-align:center; font-style:italic; margin-top:30px; font-size:0.9em;"} **Open problem:** No general *analytic proof* of color confinement in QCD is known. (It is one of the Clay Millennium Prize problems.) ::: ::: :::: ## QCD at Low Energies :::: {.columns} ::: {.column style="margin-top:40px; width:65%;" } ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:80px;} - For $\mu \sim \Lambda_{\text{QCD}}$: - $\alpha_s(\mu)$ is large - Perturbation theory breaks down ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"} - QCD physics is dominated by **non-perturbative phenomena**: - Confinement - Mass gap - Hadron spectrum & structure ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3"} - Need appropriate **Low Enery tools**: - **Lattice QCD** (first-principles numerical approach) - **Effective Field Theories** (low-energy approximations) ::: ::: ::: {.column width="35%"} ::: :::: ## Lattice QCD :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="65%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:5px;"} - **Euclidean formulation**: Discretize space-time as a **4D grid** ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - Introduces two natural **cutoffs**: - **UV** : lattice spacing $a$ - **IR** : finite size $L$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - **Fields on the lattice**: - Quarks: $\;\psi(x) \;\;\to\;\; a^{-3/2}\psi(n)$ (sites) - Gauge fields: $\;A_\mu(x) \;\;\to\;\; U_\mu(n) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$ (links) ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - Gauge links act as **parallel transporters** ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-8px;"} - **Boundary conditions**: - Periodic (PBC) for gauge fields - Anti-periodic (APBC) for fermions ::: ::: ::: {.column width="35%"}
::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-20px; margin-left:400px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:right;"} QCD becomes a set of **dimensionless variables**
It can be solved numerically using **[Monte Carlo techniques]{style="color: #EB811B;"}** ::: ## Monte Carlo methods
$$ \langle \mathcal{O}\rangle = \frac{1}{Z}\int [dU]\textcolor{blue}{[d\bar\psi d\psi]}\,\mathcal{O}\, e^{-S_G[U]-\textcolor{blue}{\bar\psi} D[U]\textcolor{blue}{\psi}} = \frac{1}{Z}\int [dU]\,\mathcal{O}_F[U]\,\textcolor{blue}{\det D[U]}\,e^{-S_G[U]} $$
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="70%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:-20px; margin-bottom:-30px;"} 1. **Importance sampling** Draw gauge configurations $\small \left\{ U_\mu^{(i)} \right\}$ from:
$$ \mathcal{P}[U]\propto e^{-S_G[U]}\,\det D[U] $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px;"} 2. $\small \forall i$ compute **observable** $\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_F[U^{(i)}]$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px; margin-bottom:-20px;"} 3. Ensemble average (**estimator**)
$$ \overline{\mathcal{O}} \;=\; \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_F[U^{(i)}] \;=\; \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle \;+\; \delta\mathcal{O} $$
::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-30px;"} 4. Set the **physical scale** $\small a$ (e.g. hadron masses) ::: ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px;"} 5. **Continuum / infinite-volume limits**:
- Remove the **UV** ($\small a \to 0$) and **IR** ($\small L \to \infty$) cut-off - (if needed) **chiral extrapolation** $\small m_q\to m_q^{\rm phys}$
::: ::: ::: {.column width="30%"} ::: {.fragment style="margin-top:60px;"} | **Experiments** | **Lattice QCD** | |------------|------------| | Accelerators (LHC) | Ensemble of configurations | | Detectors (CMS, ATLAS) | Observables | ::: ::: :::: ## Why we need strong machines?
$$ \text{Computational cost} \sim c \;\times\; (\# \text{confs}) \;\times\; \left(\frac{1}{M_\pi}\right)^6 \;\times\; L^5 \;\times\; (a^{-1})^7 $$
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {.fragment style="margin-top:-20px;"} - Cost grows rapidly when approaching: - **physical pion masses** - **large volumes** - **fine lattice spacing** ::: ::: {.fragment} - At the **physical point** with $L=32$: - Generating $3\times 10^3$
→ **$2\times 10^6$ core hours** configurations - Without parallelization on a stand-alone PC
→ **~230 years** ::: ::: {.fragment} - Data per configuration: $\mathcal{O}(1\text{-}50)$ GB → **Tera/Petabytes of data** generated ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {.fragment} **HPC** resources provide: 1. Hundreds of nodes with CPUs/GPUs 2. High memory per node 3. High network bandwidth ::: ::: :::: ## ### A remark: > "**Numerical simulations have the reputation of being an approximate method** that mainly serves to obtain qualitative information on the behaviour of complex systems.

This is, however, not so **in Lattice QCD**, where the **simulations produce results that are exact** (on the given lattice) **up to statistical errors**. The systematic uncertainties related to a non-zero lattice spacing and finite volume, still need to be investigated, but these effects are theoretically well understood, and can usually be brought under control."
— M. Lüscher
"Lattice QCD - From Quarks Confinement to Asymptotic Freedom"
## Chiral Symmetry in QCD :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1"} - **Massless QCD Lagrangian** $\small \mathrm{SU}(N_f)_L \times \mathrm{SU}(N_f)_R$ symmetry ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"} - **Exact Realization?** No! → We do not observe **parity doubling** ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3"} - Chiral symmetry is **broken**: - **Spontaneously**: $\langle \bar{\psi}\psi \rangle \neq 0$ - **Explicitly**: quark masses $m_q \neq 0$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4"} - Consequence: **Pseudo–Goldstone bosons** → light pions emerge ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5" style="margin-top:10px;"} - **Gell-Mann–Oakes–Renner (GMOR) relation**:
$$\small M_\pi^2 \;=\; (m_u + m_d)\frac{\langle \bar{\psi}\psi\rangle}{f_\pi^2} $$
::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6"} **Why an EFT?**
- At **low energies**, quarks & gluons are not convenient d.o.f. - Relevant excitations are **pions**
::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="7" style="margin-top:10px;"} **How?**
- Keep underlying symmetries - Expand in $p/\Lambda$ - Emergence of **Low Energy Constants**
::: ::: :::: ## Chiral Lagrangian (LO)
$$ \mathcal{L}_\mathrm{LO} \;=\; \frac{\textcolor{red}{f^2_\pi}}{4}\,\mathrm{Tr}\!\left[\partial_\mu U\, \partial^\mu U^\dagger\right] \;+\; \frac{\textcolor{red}{f^2_\pi} \textcolor{blue}{B}}{2}\,\mathrm{Tr}\!\left[M\,(U+U^\dagger)\right] $$
:::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:60px; margin-left:0px; text-align:left;"} At LO Life is easy → **two** Low-Energy Constants (LECs): 1. $\textcolor{red}{f}$ pion decay constant 2. $\textcolor{blue}{B}$ (related to quark condensate ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:300px; text-align:center; color:gray; font-style:italic;"} They must be fixed from **experiments** or from **Lattice QCD** ::: ::: :::: ## Chiral Lagrangian (NLO) $$\small \begin{aligned} \mathcal L_{\mathrm{eff}}^{\mathrm{NLO}}=& \frac{\ell_{1}}{4}\left\{\mathrm{Tr}[D_{\mu}U(D^{\mu}U)^{\dagger}]\right\}^{2}+\frac{\ell_{2}}{4}\mathrm{Tr}[D_{\mu}U(D_{\nu}U)^{\dagger}]\mathrm{Tr}[D^{\mu}U(D^{\nu}U)^{\dagger}] +\frac{\ell_{3}}{16}\left[\mathrm{Tr}(\chi U^{\dagger}+U\chi^{\dagger})\right]^{2}\\&+\frac{\ell_{4}}{4}\mathrm{Tr}[D_{\mu}U(D^{\mu}\chi)^{\dagger}+D_{\mu}\chi(D^{\mu}U)^{\dagger}]+\ell_{5}\left[\mathrm{Tr}(f_{\mu\nu}^{~R}Uf_{L}^{~\mu\nu}U^{\dagger})-\frac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}(f_{\mu\nu}^{~L}f_{L}^{~\mu\nu}+f_{\mu\nu}^{~R}f_{R}^{~\mu\nu})\right] \\ &+i\frac{\ell_{6}}{2}\mathrm{Tr}[f_{\mu\nu}^{~R}D^{\mu}U(D^{\nu}U)^{\dagger}+f_{\mu\nu}^{~L}(D^{\mu}U)^{\dagger}D^{\nu}U]-{\color{ #EB811B} \frac{\ell_{7}}{16}\left[\mathrm{Tr}(\chi U^{\dagger}-U\chi^{\dagger})\right]^{2}} +\frac{h_{1}+h_{3}}{4}\mathrm{Tr}(\chi\chi^{\dagger})\\&+\frac{h_{1}-h_{3}}{16}\left\{\left[\mathrm{Tr}(\chi U^{\dagger}+U\chi^{\dagger})\right]^{2}\right. +\left[\mathrm{Tr}(\chi U^{\dagger}-U\chi^{\dagger})\right]^{2}-2\mathrm{Tr}(\chi U^{\dagger}\chi U^{\dagger}+U\chi^{\dagger}U\chi^{\dagger})\Big\} \\ &-2h_{2}\mathrm{Tr}(f_{\mu\nu}^{~L}f_{L}^{~\mu\nu}+f_{\mu\nu}^{~R}f_{R}^{~\mu\nu})) \end{aligned} $$ :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:20px; margin-left:0px; text-align:left;"} - Emergence of new Physical effects ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-0px; margin-left:0px; text-align:left;"} - Among all the NLO LECs $\ell_7$ is the least known - **Never determined directly** ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:-0px; margin-left:0px; text-align:left;"} - Related to Axion Phenomenology ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: :::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:-0px; margin-left:0px; text-align:left;"} ::: ## Our work ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:-30px; margin-left:0px; text-align:left;"} ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-5px; margin-left:20px; text-align:left;"} 1. Improved precision 2. Universality test 3. Controlled **continuum** and **chiral** extrapolations ::: # (A few) Open Problems and Challenges ## Topological Freezing :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:-10px;"} - No trivial **topology** - Special classical solutions of QCD → **Istantons** - Carry an integer **topological charge $Q$** - Transitions between sectors → **tunneling** over energy barriers ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-100px; margin-left:-110px; text-align:center;"} ::: ::: ::: {.column width="55%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-60px; text-align:center;"} ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:-60px;"} **Twofold Problem**: 1. Simulation issues: → Std Alghorithms **fail** as $\small a \to 0$ 2. Phenomenological issues: → **Thermodynamics** of the early universe → **Cold** and **Hot** Axion Phenomenology → **Singlet** particle properties ::: ::: :::: ## Possible Solutions :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:30px; margin-left:30px;"} - **Parallel Tempering** - Run **several copies** at different **temperatures or boundary conditions** simultaneously - Swap configurations between them: - 1 “physical” - N “eased” replicas ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:50px; margin-left:30px;"} - Works well in pure gauge - **Fermionic determinant**? - Requires **fine-tuning** of the tower of copies ::: ::: ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:10px;"} - Other possible solutions: - Metadynamics - Open Boundary conditions - Normalizing Flows? ::: ::: :::: ## Inverse Problem/ Analytical Continuation **Correlators** are related to **spectral function** via an **inverse Fourier transform** $$\small C(t)=\int dE\; \exp{\left[-iEt\right]} \rho(E) $$ in **Minkowski time** ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:10px;"} - Simulations are performed in **Euclidean time** ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-10px;"} - It means solving an **inverse Laplace problem** - This is **ill-posed** and **numerically unstable** ::: :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="40%"} ::: ::: {.column width="60%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:-175px;margin-left:140px;"} $$\begin{aligned}\small \hat \rho_\sigma(E) \;=\; \int dE_0 \; \sigma(E,E_0)\,\rho(E_0)\\ \small C_\sigma(t) \;=\; \int dE \; e^{-Et} \,\rho_\sigma(E). \end{aligned} $$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-15px;margin-left:100px;"} - **Backus-Gilbert method** - Construct smeared spectral function ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5" style="margin-top:15px; margin-left:100px;"} - **Bayesian approaches** (MEM, BR, etc.) ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6" style="margin-top:-15px; margin-left:100px;"} - **Other approaches**: - Neural networks, Deep-learning... ::: ::: :::: ## Application to the Sphaleron Rate :::: {.columns} ::: {.column width="55%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:-10px;"} - **Sphaleron rate** ⇔ **frequency of topological transitions** ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-10px;"} - Measure **topological charge correlator** in Euclidean time $$\small C(t) = \langle Q(t) Q(0) \rangle $$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-10px;"} - Need **real-time sphaleron rate**: $$\small \Gamma_\mathrm{sphal} \sim \lim_{\omega\to 0} \frac{\rho(\omega)}{\omega} $$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:-10px;"} - Challenges: **ill-posed**, noisy data, limited temporal extent ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5" style="margin-top:-10px;"} - Application of **Backus-Gilbert** method ::: ::: ::: {.column width="45%"} ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6" style="margin-top:-15px; margin-left:0;"} ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6" style="margin-top:0px;"} $$ \small \frac{\Gamma_\mathrm{sphal}}{T^4} = 0.079(25) \qquad T=1.24T_c $$ ::: ::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="7" style="margin-top:-10px;"} **To-do**: Extension to non-zero momentum ::: ::: :::: ## That's not all ::: {style="position: absolute; top: 20px; width:100%; text-align:center; font-size:2em;"} Maaaaany Open Problems in Lattice QCD :::
**Topology & sampling**
Topological freezing
Autocorrelations
Rare-event sampling
**Analytic continuation & spectra**
Analytic continuation / inverse Laplace problem
Multi-particle states & finite volume effects
Excited-state contamination
**Fermion-related challenges**
Signal-to-noise problem in baryons
Disconnected diagrams
Chiral symmetry / small quark masses
**QED corrections**
QED corrections
Isospin breaking effects
**Finite temperature / density**
Finite-temperature QCD
Real-time dynamics / transport coefficients
QCD at finite baryon density (sign problem)
**CP & beyond Standard Model**
CP-violating observables
Neutron EDM
Rare decays
**Computational & algorithmic**
Continuum / infinite-volume extrapolation
Efficient solvers for Dirac operator
Scaling to exascale HPC
**Machine Learning / AI applications**
Accelerating gauge configuration sampling
Normalizing flows for topological sectors
Surrogate models for correlators
Bayesian inference for spectral reconstruction
::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="text-align:center; margin-top:-200px; margin-left:550px; font-style: italic; font-size:1.3em;"} Lattice QCD is full of challenges Just pick one, dive in and [**have fun**]{style="color: #EB811B;"}! ::: # Thank you for your attention
